{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox military person |name=Sergeant Stubby |birth_date=1916 |death_date=March 16, {{death year and age|1926|1916}}{{cite book|last1=Bausum |first1=Ann |first2=David E., Foreword |last2=Sharpe |title=Sergeant Stubby: How a Stray Dog and His Best Friend Helped Win World War I and Stole the Heart of a Nation|date=2014|location=Washington, D.C |type=Print |publisher=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|isbn=978-1426213106|page=220}} |birth_place= |death_place= |placeofburial=Smithsonian "The Price of Freedom" exhibition |placeofburial_label=Place of display |image=Sergeant Stubby.jpg |caption=Sergeant Stubby c. 1920 |allegiance={{Flag|United States of America|1912|size=23px}} |branch=[[File:Seal of the United States Department of War.png|25px]] [[United States Army]] |serviceyears= 1917-1918 |rank=[[File:WW1-Sergeant.svg|25px]] [[Sergeant#United States Army|Sergeant]] |unit=[[102nd Infantry Regiment (United States)|102nd Infantry Regiment]], [[26th Infantry Division (United States)|26th (Yankee) Division]] |battles=[[World War I]] * 17 battles on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] |awards=Humane Education Society Gold Medal
[[Wound stripe]] |laterwork=[[Georgetown Hoyas]]' mascot }} Sergeant '''Stubby''' (1916 – March 16, 1926) was a [[dog]] who is the official mascot of the [[102nd Infantry Regiment (United States)]] and was assigned to the [[26th Infantry Division (United States)|26th (Yankee) Division]] in [[World War I]]. He served for 18 months and participated in seventeen battles on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]]. He saved his regiment from surprise [[mustard gas]] attacks, found and comforted the wounded, and once caught a German soldier by the seat of his pants, holding him there until American soldiers found him.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} His actions were well-documented in contemporary American newspapers.{{cite web |url=http://historywired.si.edu/detail.cfm?ID=519 |work=History wired |publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]] |title=Stubby, World War I Canine Hero 1921 |accessdate=July 15, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141117131914/http://historywired.si.edu/detail.cfm?ID=519 |archivedate=November 17, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/history/2014/05/dogs_of_war_sergeant_stubby_the_u_s_army_s_original_and_still_most_highly.html |title=Sergeant Stubby: America’s original dog of war fought bravely on the Western Front—then helped the nation forget the Great War’s terrible human toll |first1=Gillian |last1=Kane |first2=Lisa, Illustrator |last2=Larson-Walker |date=May 7, 2014 |publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate.com]] |accessdate=July 13, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713085216/http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/history/2014/05/dogs_of_war_sergeant_stubby_the_u_s_army_s_original_and_still_most_highly.html |archivedate=July 13, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} Reprinted in {{cite news |title=The story of Sergeant Stubby, WWI's most decorated dog |url=http://www.stripes.com/news/us/the-story-of-sergeant-stubby-wwi-s-most-decorated-dog-1.285051 |first1=Gillian |last1=Kane |newspaper=[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars & Stripes]] |date=May 24, 2014 |accessdate=July 17, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701113942/http://www.stripes.com/news/us/the-story-of-sergeant-stubby-wwi-s-most-decorated-dog-1.285051 |archivedate=July 1, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://www.ct.gov/mil/cwp/view.asp?a=1351&q=257958 |publisher=Connecticut Military History |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 4, 1926 – July 16, 2003 |title=Stubby's Obituary: Stubby of A.E.F. Enters Valhalla |accessdate=July 15, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140802035203/http://www.ct.gov/mil/cwp/view.asp?a=1351&q=257958 |archivedate=August 2, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} Stubby has been called the most decorated [[war dog]] of [[World War I]], and the only dog to be nominated for rank and then promoted to [[Sergeant#United States|sergeant]] through combat,{{cite web |url=http://amhistory.si.edu/militaryhistory/exhibition/flash.html?path=8.1.r_15 |publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]] |title="The Price of Freedom" exhibition |accessdate=July 14, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140624031648/http://amhistory.si.edu/militaryhistory/exhibition/flash.html?path=8.1.r_15 |archivedate=June 24, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} a claim having no official documentary evidence, but recognized in connection with an exhibition at the [[Smithsonian Institution]]. Stubby is the subject of a [[Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero|2018 animated film]]. ==Early life== Stubby was described in contemporaneous news items as a [[Bull Terrier]] or [[Boston Terrier]].{{cite web |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1921-07-09/ed-1/seq-18/#date1=1836&index=0&rows=20&words=Boston+STUBBY&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1922&proxtext=stubby+boston&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1ID=15%201 |title=Evening Public Ledger. (Philadelphia [Pa.]) 1914-1942, July 09, 1921, NIGHT EXTRA, Image 18 |website=Chroniclingamerica.loc.gov |agency=[[Library of Congress]] |location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania |date=1921-07-09 |accessdate=February 6, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055031/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1921-07-09/ed-1/seq-18/#date1=1836&index=0&rows=20&words=Boston+STUBBY&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1922&proxtext=stubby+boston&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1ID=15%201 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} Describing him as a dog of "uncertain breed", Ann Bausum wrote that "The brindle-patterned pup probably owed at least some of his parentage to the evolving family of Boston Terriers, a breed so new that even its name was in flux: Boston Round Heads, American Bull Terriers, and Boston Bull Terriers."{{cite book|last1=Bausum |first1=Ann |first2=David E., Foreword |last2=Sharpe |title=Sergeant Stubby: How a Stray Dog and His Best Friend Helped Win World War I and Stole the Heart of a Nation|date=2014|location=Washington, D.C |type=Print |publisher=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|isbn=978-1426213106|page=23}} Stubby was found wandering the grounds of the [[Yale University]] campus in [[New Haven]], [[Connecticut]] in July 1917, while members of the 102nd Infantry were training. The dog hung around as the men drilled and one soldier, Corporal Robert Conroy, developed a fondness for him. When it came time for the outfit to ship out, Conroy hid Stubby on board the troop ship. As they were getting off the ship in France, he hid Stubby under his overcoat without detection. Upon discovery by Conroy's commanding officer, Stubby saluted him as he had been trained to in camp, and the commanding officer allowed the dog to stay on board. ==Military service== [[File:Sergeant Stubby 2.jpg|thumb|left|Sergeant Stubby wearing his coat and medals]] Stubby served with the 102nd Infantry Regiment in the [[trenches]] in [[France]] for 8 months and participated in four offensives and 17 battles. He entered combat on February 5, 1918, at [[Chemin des Dames]], north of [[Soissons]], and was under constant fire, day and night for over a month. In April 1918, during a raid to take Seicheprey, Stubby was wounded in the foreleg by the retreating Germans throwing [[hand grenades]]. He was sent to the rear for convalescence, and as he had done on the front was able to improve morale. When he recovered from his wounds, Stubby returned to the trenches. He ultimately had two wound stripes.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1019&dat=19211028&id=4PEyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eQ4GAAAAIBAJ&pg=1227,553446 |title=Dog Hero Again Honored |newspaper=Roundup Record-Tribune & Winnett Times |date=October 28, 1921 |page=10}} In his first year of battle Stubby was injured by mustard gas. After he recovered, he returned with a specially designed gas mask to protect him.Marie Lux, Anna. "Janesville author breathes new life into Stubby the war dog". ''The Janesville Gazette'' (WI). 2014. Also, he learned to warn his unit of [[poison gas]] attacks, located wounded soldiers in [[no man's land]], and—since he could hear the whine of incoming artillery shells before humans—became very adept at letting his unit know when to duck for cover. He was solely responsible for capturing a German spy in the [[Meuse-Argonne Offensive|Argonne]], leading to the commander of the 102 Infantry to nominate Stubby for the rank of sergeant. However, whether Stubby was actually promoted or even an official member of the Army has been disputed.{{cite book|last1=Bausum |first1=Ann |first2=David E., Foreword |last2=Sharpe |title=Sergeant Stubby: How a Stray Dog and His Best Friend Helped Win World War I and Stole the Heart of a Nation|date=2014|location=Washington, D.C |type=Print |publisher=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|isbn=978-1426213106|page=112}} Following the retaking of [[Château-Thierry]] by the US, the women of the town made Stubby a chamois coat on which were pinned his many medals. He also helped free a French town from the Germans.{{Citation needed|date=November 2015}} He was later injured in the chest and leg by a grenade. At the end of the war, Robert Conroy smuggled Stubby home. ==After the war== After returning home, Stubby became a celebrity and marched in, and normally led, many parades across the country. He met Presidents [[Woodrow Wilson]], [[Calvin Coolidge]], and [[Warren G. Harding]]. In 1921 General [[John J. Pershing]] presented a gold medal from the [[The Humane Society of the United States|Humane Education Society]] to Stubby, which was the subject of a famous photograph. Starting in 1921, he attended [[Georgetown University Law Center]] with Conroy, and became the [[Georgetown Hoyas]]' [[Jack the Bulldog|team mascot]].{{cite web |first1=Major General Thaddeus |last1=Martin |url=http://www.ct.gov/mil/cwp/view.asp?a=1351&q=257892 |title=Stubby the Military Dog |date=April 12, 2011 |publisher=Connecticut Military department |accessdate=February 6, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303181830/http://www.ct.gov/mil/cwp/view.asp?a=1351&q=257892 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} He would be given the [[American football|football]] at [[halftime]] and would nudge the ball around the field to the amusement of the fans.{{cite news |url=http://www.governorsfootguard.com/stubby/ |title=A Connecticut Hero: Sgt. Stubby |accessdate=January 9, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150117094125/http://www.governorsfootguard.com/stubby/ |archivedate=January 17, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}*{{cite book |author=Richmond, Derek |newspaper=[[The Hoya]] |publisher=[[Georgetown University]] |location=Georgetown, Washington, D.C |url=http://www.thehoya.com/from-mascot-to-military-stubby-left-pawprints-on-hilltop-and-beyond/ |title=From Mascot to Military, Stubby Left Pawprints on Hilltop and Beyond |date=November 4, 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141029150637/http://www.thehoya.com/from-mascot-to-military-stubby-left-pawprints-on-hilltop-and-beyond/ |archivedate=October 29, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} Stubby died in his sleep in 1926. After his death, he was preserved with his skin mounted on a plaster cast. Conroy presented Stubby to the Smithsonian in 1956. ==Legacy== [[File:Sgt Stubby's brick at Liberty Memorial.jpg|thumb|Sergeant Stubby's brick at the Liberty Memorial]] Stubby received an [[obituary]] in the ''[[New York Times]]'' following his death in 1926. The obituary was half a page, which was much longer than the obituaries of many notable people of the time. Stubby was the subject of a portrait by "Capitol artist" Charles Ayer Whipple. He was featured in the ''Brave Beasts'' exhibit at the [[Legermuseum]] in [[Delft]], [[The Netherlands]] July 18, 2008 – April 13, 2009.{{cite web |url= http://www.armymuseum.nl/legermuseum.en/legermuseum.en/i000466.html |title= Brave Beasts |work= Legermuseum |date= July 18, 2008 |accessdate= December 21, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091209223652/http://www.armymuseum.nl/legermuseum.en/legermuseum.en/i000466.html |archivedate= December 9, 2009 |df= mdy-all }} During a ceremony held on [[Armistice Day]] in 2006, a brick was placed in the Walk of Honor at the [[Liberty Memorial]] in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] to commemorate Sergeant Stubby.{{cite web |url=http://message.snopes.com/showthread.php?t=83485 |title=Stubby |date=November 11, 2006 |publisher=[[Snopes.com]] |accessdate=July 14, 2014}} Stubby was the subject of at least four books.{{cite book |title=Stubby the War Dog: The True Story of World War I's Bravest Dog |type=Hardcover/audio |date=May 13, 2014 |first1=Ann |last1=Bausum |pages=80 |publisher=National Geographic Children's Books |location=Washington D.C. |isbn=1426314868 }}{{cite book |title=Stubby, Brave Soldier Dog |work=Famous Animal Stories |type=Hardcover |first1=Richard |last1=Glendinning |first2=Sally |last2=Glendinning |first3=Richard |last3=Amundsen |page=48 |location=Champaign, Illinois |publisher=Garrard Pub. Co./Olympic Marketing Corp |year= 1978 |isbn=0811648648 }}{{cite book |title=The Most Decorated Dog In History: Sergeant Stubby |edition=Kindle |first1=Isabel |last1=George |type=Print |page=304 |publisher=[[Harper Collins]] |year= 2012 |asin=B00739VSKW}} In 2014, [[BBC Schools]] World War One series used Stubby as a Famous Figure to help teach children about the war, along with creating an animated comic strip to illustrate his life.{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/0/ww1/25827997 |title= BBC Schools World War One |work= BBC |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150219152323/http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/0/ww1/25827997 |archivedate= February 19, 2015 |df= mdy-all }}{{cite web|url= http://vimeo.com/90374659|title= Animation: Sergeant Stubby|work= BBC|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150704001021/https://vimeo.com/90374659|archivedate= July 4, 2015|df= mdy-all}} Stubby has his portrait on display at the West Haven Military Museum in Connecticut. ''[[Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero]]'' is an animated feature-length film based on the life and times of Stubby, which was theatrically released on April 13, 2018.{{cite web |url= http://www.stubbythemovie.com |title= Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero |work= Official Homepage. |accessdate= March 11, 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160311070253/http://www.stubbythemovie.com/ |archivedate= March 11, 2016 |df= mdy-all }}{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5314190/combined |title= Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero |publisher= [[IMDb]] |accessdate= March 11, 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160108041952/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt5314190/combined |archivedate= January 8, 2016 |df= mdy-all }} The film features the voices of [[Logan Lerman]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/logan-lerman-enlists-for-fun-academy-motion-pictures-animated-feature-sgt-stubby-300420357.html|title=Logan Lerman Enlists for Fun Academy Motion Pictures' Animated Feature SGT. STUBBY|last=Pictures|first=Fun Academy Motion|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308181307/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/logan-lerman-enlists-for-fun-academy-motion-pictures-animated-feature-sgt-stubby-300420357.html|archivedate=March 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} [[Helena Bonham Carter]],{{Cite web|url=http://theslanted.com/2016/07/24115/helena-bonham-carter-joins-cast-of-animated-tale-sgt-stubby/|title=Helena Bonham Carter joins cast of animated tale "Sgt Stubby"|date=2016-07-26|website=The Slanted|access-date=2016-07-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160727132414/http://theslanted.com/2016/07/24115/helena-bonham-carter-joins-cast-of-animated-tale-sgt-stubby/|archivedate=July 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}} and [[Gérard Depardieu]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/award-winning-actor-gerard-depardieu-joins-cast-of-sgt-stubby-an-american-hero-300274852.html|title=Award Winning Actor Gérard Depardieu Joins Cast of Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero|last=Studio|first=Fun Academy Motion Pictures|website=www.prnewswire.com|access-date=2016-07-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160715061741/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/award-winning-actor-gerard-depardieu-joins-cast-of-sgt-stubby-an-american-hero-300274852.html|archivedate=July 15, 2016|df=mdy-all}} with music by [[Academy Award]] nominee [[Patrick Doyle]]. The animation was made by the studio [[Mikros Image]].{{Cite web|url=https://stubbymovie.wordpress.com/2017/01/23/fun-academy-and-mikros-images-sgt-stubby-slated-to-open-on-april-13-2018/|title=Fun Academy and Mikros Image’s SGT. STUBBY Slated to Open on April 13, 2018|last=Hero|first=Sgt Stubby: An American|date=2017-01-24|website=Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero|access-date=2017-06-12}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} It has also been endorsed as an official project of the [[United States World War I Centennial Commission]].{{cite web |url= http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/stubby--an-american-hero-named-official-film-partner-of-the-united-states-world-war-i-centennial-commission-300177722.html |title= Stubby – An American Hero Named Official Film Partner Of The United States World War I Centennial Commission |publisher= [[PRNewswire]] |date= November 12, 2015 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160311070117/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/stubby--an-american-hero-named-official-film-partner-of-the-united-states-world-war-i-centennial-commission-300177722.html |archivedate= March 11, 2016 |df= mdy-all }} The descendants of Robert Conroy (Stubby's inseparable companion) dedicated a life-size bronze statue of Stubby named "Stubby Salutes", by Susan Bahary, in the Connecticut Trees of Honor Memorial at Veteran's Memorial Park in Middletown, Connecticut in May 2018. The statue pays tribute to fallen Connecticut veterans. Both Stubby and Robert Conroy were from Connecticut.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|United States Army|World War I|Connecticut}} *[[Cher Ami]], carrier pigeon who is displayed with Stubby in the Smithsonian Institution's Americans at War: The Price of Freedom exhibit. *[[Chips (dog)|Chips]], most decorated dog from [[World War II]] *[[Dogs in warfare]] *[[List of individual dogs]] *[[Military animal]] *[[Owney (dog)|Owney]], famous postal mascot dog and world traveler, also on display at the Smithsonian Institution *[[Rags (dog)]] *[[Smoky (dog)|Smoky]], World War II [[Yorkshire terrier]] war dog, credited with 12 combat missions and awarded 8 battle stars. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|last1=Bausum|first1=Ann|title=Sergeant Stubby: How a Stray Dog and His Best Friend Helped Win World War I and Stole the Heart of a Nation|date=2014 |first2=David E., Foreword |last2=Sharpe |location=Washington, DC |type=Print |publisher=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|isbn=978-1426213106|page=112}} * {{cite book |title=Stubby the War Dog: The True Story of World War I's Bravest Dog |type=Hardcover/audio |date=2014 |first1=Ann |last1=Bausum |page=80 |publisher=National Geographic Children's Books |location=Washington DC |isbn=1426314868 }} * {{cite book |last1=Furstinger|first1=Nancy |title=Paws of Courage: True Stories of Heroic Dogs that Protect and Serve |type=hardcover |page=160|publisher=National Geographic Children's Books |edition=1st |date=2016 |isbn=978-1426323775}} * {{cite book |last1=Garden|first1=Joe |first2=Chris |last2=Pauls |first3=Janet |last3=Ginsburg|title=The Dangerous Book for Dogs: A Parody by Rex and Sparky |type=hardcover |pages=208 |publisher=Villard |edition=1st |date=2007 |isbn=978-0345503701}} * {{cite book |title=The Most Decorated Dog In History: Sergeant Stubby |edition=Kindle |first1=Isabel |last1=George |type=Print |page=304 |publisher=[[Harper Collins]] |date=March 8, 2012 |asin=B00739VSKW}} * {{cite book |title=Stubby, Brave Soldier Dog |work=Famous Animal Stories |type=Hardcover |first1=Richard |last1=Glendinning |first2=Sally |last2=Glendinning |first3=Richard |last3=Amundsen |page=48 |location=Champaign, Illinois |publisher=Garrard Pub. Co./Olympic Marketing Corp |date=October 1978 |isbn=0811648648 }} * {{cite book |last1=Goodavage |first1=Maria|title=Soldier Dogs|location=New York |date=March 15, 2012 |type=Hardcover |pages=293 |publisher=Dutton Adult |edition=1 |isbn=0525952780 }} * {{cite book |last1=Stone |first1=Barry |title=The Diggers' Menagerie: Mates, Mascots and Marvels – True Stories of Animals Who Went to War |publisher=[[HarperCollins]]/[[ABC Books]] |location=Australia |page=215 |date= 2012 |asin=B0062GO7FK}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *{{Find a Grave|12236483}} *[http://www.ct.gov/mil/cwp/view.asp?a=1351&q=257958 Obituary from the ''New York Times''] (archived at the Connecticut Military Department) *{{cite web |url=http://blog.usamm.com/sergeant-stubby-the-war-dog/ |title=Sergeant Stubby the War Dog |accessdate=July 15, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140719040209/http://blog.usamm.com/sergeant-stubby-the-war-dog/ |archivedate=July 19, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} *{{cite web |author=Irwin, Tanya |publisher=[[Toledo Blade]] |location=Toledo, Ohio |title= Canine soldiers earn accolades: Exhibit extols virtues of WWI’s Sgt. Stubby|url= http://www.toledoblade.com/local/2013/05/27/Canine-soldiers-earn-accolades.html |date=May 27, 2013}} *{{cite web |url=http://uswardogsmemorial.org/id16.html |publisher=War Dogs Remembered |title=First Marine Scout Dog Killed In Action |first1=2nd. Lt. Mike |last1=Pitts |year=1966 |accessdate=July 14, 2014}} *{{cite news |title=Stubby, Hero Mascot of 17 Battles, Showing Decorations for Bravery |publisher= Chronicling America |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1921-07-08/ed-1/seq-2.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=July 8, 1921 |accessdate=July 14, 2014}} *[http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/3/13 U.S. Army launches K-9 Corps] *{{cite news |publisher=I.imgur.com |url=http://i.imgur.com/A43lk3v.jpg |title=Visual of the Boston Terrier (aka Boston Bull Terrier) of 1912}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/sgt-stubby-american-war-dog/ |title=Sgt. Stubby - American War Dog |publisher=Defense Media Network |first1=Dwight Jon |last1=Zimmermman|date=July 27, 2010 |accessdate=July 14, 2014}} *{{cite web |url=http://funacademystudios.com/project/sgt-stubby-an-american-hero/ |title=Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero |publisher=Labyrinth Media/Fun Academy Motion Pictures |accessdate=March 8, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170309064535/http://funacademystudios.com/project/sgt-stubby-an-american-hero/ |archive-date=March 9, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stubby, Sergeant}} [[Category:1926 animal deaths]] [[Category:Collection of the Smithsonian Institution]] [[Category:Dog monuments]] [[Category:Former college mascots in the United States]] [[Category:Georgetown Hoyas]] [[Category:Individual dogs]] [[Category:Military animals]] [[Category:Military animals of World War I]] [[Category:Military history of the United States during World War I]] [[Category:Military in Connecticut]] [[Category:History of the United States Army]] [[Category:Working dogs]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]]

revision.comment: Alter: isbn, journal. Add: pmid, citeseerx. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{Other uses|Shock (disambiguation){{!}}Shock}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Shock | synonyms = Circulatory shock | image = | caption = | field = [[Critical care medicine]] | symptoms = '''Initial''': Weakness, fast heart rate, fast breathing, sweating, anxiety, increased thirst
'''Later''': Confusion, [[unconsciousness]], [[cardiac arrest]] | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = [[Hypovolemia#Stages of hypovolemic shock|Low volume]], [[cardiogenic shock|cardiogenic]], [[Obstructive shock|obstructive]], [[distributive shock|distributive]]{{cite book|title=ATLS - Advanced Trauma Life Support - Student Course Manual|date=2018|publisher=American College of Surgeons|isbn=978-78-0-9968267|pages=43–52, 135|edition=10}} | causes = '''Low volume''': Bleeding, vomiting, [[pancreatitis]]
'''Cardiogenic''': [[heart attack]], [[cardiac contusion]]
'''Obstructive''': [[Cardiac tamponade]], [[tension pneumothorax]]
'''Distributed''': [[Sepsis]], [[spinal cord injury]], certain [[overdose]]s | risks = | diagnosis = Based on symptoms, [[physical exam]], laboratory tests | differential = | prevention = | treatment = Based on the underlying cause | medication = [[Intravenous fluid]], [[vasopressors]] | prognosis = Risk of death 20 to 50% | frequency = 1.2 million per year (USA) | deaths = }} '''Shock''' is the state of not enough [[blood flow]] to the [[Tissue (biology)|tissue]]s of the body as a result of problems with the [[circulatory system]]. Initial symptoms may include weakness, [[fast heart rate]], [[fast breathing]], sweating, anxiety, and increased thirst. This may be followed by confusion, [[unconsciousness]], or [[cardiac arrest]] as complications worsen.{{cite book |title=International Trauma Life Support for Emergency Care Providers |date=2018 |publisher=Pearson Education Limited |isbn=978-1292-17084-8 |pages=172–173 |edition=8}} Shock is divided into four main types based on the underlying cause: [[Hypovolemia#Stages of hypovolemic shock|low volume]], [[Cardiogenic shock|cardiogenic]], [[Obstructive shock|obstructive]], and [[distributive shock]]. Low volume shock may be from bleeding, vomiting, or [[pancreatitis]]. Cardiogenic shock may be due to a [[heart attack]] or [[cardiac contusion]]. Obstructive shock may be due to [[cardiac tamponade]] or a [[tension pneumothorax]]. Distributed shock may be due to [[sepsis]], [[spinal cord injury]], or certain [[overdose]]s. The diagnosis is generally based on a combination of symptoms, [[physical examination]], and laboratory tests. A decreased [[pulse pressure]] ([[systolic blood pressure]] minus [[diastolic blood pressure]]) or a fast heart rate raises concerns. The heart rate divided by systolic blood pressure, known as the shock index (SI), of greater than 0.8 supports the diagnosis more than [[low blood pressure]] or a [[fast heart rate]] in isolation.{{cite journal |vauthors=Olaussen A, Blackburn T, Mitra B, Fitzgerald M | title=Review article: shock index for prediction of critical bleeding post-trauma: a systematic review | journal=Emergency Medicine Australasia | year=2014 | volume=26 | issue=3| pages=223–8 | pmid=24712642 | doi=10.1111/1742-6723.12232}}{{cite book |last1=Guyton |first1=Arthur |last2=Hall |first2=John |editor1-first=Rebecca |editor1-last=Gruliow |title=Textbook of Medical Physiology |edition=11th |year=2006 |publisher=Elsevier Inc. |location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania |isbn=978-0-7216-0240-0 |pages=278–288 |chapter=Chapter 24: Circulatory Shock and Physiology of Its Treatment}} Treatment of shock is based on the likely underlying cause. An open [[airway]] and sufficient [[breathing]] should be established. Any ongoing bleeding should be stopped, which may require surgery or [[embolization]]. [[Intravenous fluid]], such as [[Ringer's lactate]] or [[packed red blood cells]], is often given. Efforts to maintain a normal [[body temperature]] are also important. [[Vasopressors]] may be useful in certain cases. Shock is both common and has a high risk of death. In the United States about 1.2 million people present to the emergency room each year with shock and their risk of death is between 20 and 50%.{{cite book |last1=Tabas |first1=Jeffrey |last2=Reynolds |first2=Teri |title=High Risk Emergencies, An Issue of Emergency Medicine Clinics - E-Book |date=2010 |publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences |isbn=978-1455700257 |page=58 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=Ac_XI7P3CKwC&pg=PA58 |language=en}} {{TOC limit}} ==Signs and symptoms== The presentation of shock is variable with some people having only minimal symptoms such as confusion and weakness.{{cite book |author=Tintinalli, Judith E. |title=Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide (Emergency Medicine (Tintinalli))|publisher=McGraw-Hill Companies |location=New York |year=2010 |pages=165–172|isbn=978-0-07-148480-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} While the general signs for all types of shock are [[hypotension|low blood pressure]], decreased urine output, and confusion, these may not always be present. While a fast heart rate is common, those on [[Beta blocker|β-blockers]], those who are athletic and in 30% of cases of those with shock due to intra abdominal bleeding may have a normal or slow heart rate.{{cite book |author=Tintinalli, Judith E. |title=Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide (Emergency Medicine (Tintinalli))|publisher=McGraw-Hill Companies |location=New York |year=2010 |pages=174–175 |isbn=978-0-07-148480-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} Specific subtypes of shock may have additional symptoms. ===Low volume=== {{main|Hypovolemia}} {{Class of Hemorrhage}} [[Hypovolemia]] is a direct loss of effective circulating blood volume leading to: *A rapid, weak, thready pulse due to decreased blood flow combined with tachycardia *Cool, clammy skin due to [[vasoconstriction]] and stimulation of vasoconstriction *Rapid and shallow breathing due to sympathetic nervous system stimulation and acidosis *[[Hypothermia]] due to decreased perfusion and evaporation of sweat *Thirst and dry mouth, due to fluid depletion *Cold and mottled skin ([[Livedo reticularis]]), especially extremities, due to insufficient perfusion of the skin The severity of hemorrhagic shock can be graded on a 1–4 scale on the physical signs. This approximates to the effective loss of blood volume.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} The ''shock index'' (heart rate divided by systolic blood pressure) is a stronger predictor of the impact of blood loss than heart rate and blood pressure alone. This relationship has not been well established in pregnancy-related bleeding.{{cite journal |vauthors=Pacagnella RC, Souza JP, Durocher J, Perel P, Blum J, Winikoff B, Gülmezoglu AM | title=A systematic review of the relationship between blood loss and clinical signs | journal=PLoS ONE | year=2013 | volume=8 | issue=3| pages=e57594 | pmid=23483915 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0057594 | pmc=3590203}} ===Cardiogenic=== Symptoms of [[cardiogenic shock]] include: *Distended [[jugular vein]]s due to increased [[jugular venous pressure]] *Weak or absent pulse *[[Heart arrhythmia|Abnormal heart rhythms]], often a [[tachycardia|fast heart rate]] *[[Pulsus paradoxus]] in case of [[Cardiac tamponade|tamponade]] *Reduced blood pressure ===Obstructive=== [[Obstructive shock]] includes [[cardiac tamponade]], [[pulmonary embolism]], and [[tension pneumothorax]]. ===Distributive=== {{SIRS}} [[Distributive shock]] includes [[Sepsis|infectious]], [[Anaphylaxis|anaphylactic]], [[endocrine]] (e.g., [[adrenal insufficiency]]), [[salicylate toxicity]], and [[Neurogenic shock|neurogenic]] causes. The [[Systemic inflammatory response syndrome|SIRS]] features typically occur in early septic shock. ====Septic shock==== *Systemic [[leukocyte]] adhesion to endothelial cells *Reduced contractility of the heart *Activation of the coagulation pathways, resulting in [[disseminated intravascular coagulation]] *Increased levels of [[neutrophils]] Main manifestations are produced due to massive release of [[histamine]] which causes intense dilation of the blood vessels. People with septic shock will also likely be positive for the SIRS criteria. The most generally accepted treatment for these patients is early recognition of symptoms, and early administration of broad spectrum and organism specific antibiotics.{{cite web|title=Surviving Sepsis Campaign Responds to ProCESS Trial|url=http://www.survivingsepsis.org/SiteCollectionDocuments/SSC-Responds-Process-Trial.pdf|website=Surviving Sepsis Campaign|publisher=Survivingsepsis.org|accessdate=2015-03-25}} ==Cause== Shock is a common end point of many medical conditions.{{cite journal|last=Silverman|first=Adam|title=Shock: A Common Pathway For Life-Threatening Pediatric Illnesses And Injuries|journal=Pediatric Emergency Medicine Practice|date=Oct 2005|volume=2|issue=10|url=http://www.ebmedicine.net/topics.php?paction=showTopic&topic_id=149}} It has been divided into four main types based on the underlying cause: hypovolemic, distributive, cardiogenic, and obstructive.{{cite book |author=Tintinalli, Judith E. |title=Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide (Emergency Medicine (Tintinalli))|publisher=McGraw-Hill Companies |location=New York |year=2010 |pages=168 |isbn=978-0-07-148480-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} A few additional classifications are occasionally used including: endocrinologic shock. ===Low volume=== [[Hypovolemic shock]] is the most common type of shock and is caused by insufficient circulating [[blood volume|volume]]. Its primary cause is [[haemorrhage]] (internal or external), or loss of fluid from the [[Circulatory system|circulation]]. [[Vomiting]] and [[diarrhea]] are the most common cause in children. Other causes include burns, environmental exposure, and excess urine loss due to [[diabetic ketoacidosis]] and [[diabetes insipidus]]. ===Cardiogenic=== [[Cardiogenic shock]] is caused by the failure of the heart to pump effectively. This can be due to damage to the heart muscle, most often from a large [[myocardial infarction]]. Other causes of cardiogenic shock include [[cardiac dysrhythmia|dysrhythmia]]s, [[cardiomyopathy]]/[[myocarditis]], [[congestive heart failure]] (CHF), [[Myocardial contusion|contusio cordis]], or [[valvular heart disease]] problems. ===Obstructive=== [[Obstructive shock]] is due to obstruction of blood flow outside of the heart. Several conditions can result in this form of shock. *[[Cardiac tamponade]] in which fluid in the pericardium prevents inflow of blood into the heart (venous return). [[Constrictive pericarditis]], in which the [[pericardium]] shrinks and hardens, is similar in presentation. *[[Tension pneumothorax]] Through increased intrathoracic pressure, bloodflow to the heart is prevented (venous return). *[[Pulmonary embolism]] is the result of a thromboembolic incident in the blood vessels of the [[lung]]s and hinders the return of blood to the heart. *[[Aortic stenosis]] hinders circulation by obstructing the [[ventricular outflow tract]] *[[Hypertrophic sub-aortic stenosis]] is overly thick ventricular muscle dynamically occludes the [[ventricular outflow tract]]. ===Distributive=== [[Distributive shock]] is due to impaired utilization of oxygen and thus production of energy by the cell. Examples of this form of shock are: *[[Septic shock]] is the most common cause of distributive shock. Caused by an overwhelming systemic infection resulting in [[vasodilation]] leading to hypotension. Septic shock can be caused by [[Gram negative]] bacteria such as (among others) ''[[Escherichia coli]]'', Proteus species, ''[[Klebsiella pneumoniae]]'' which have an [[endotoxin]] on their surface which produces adverse biochemical, immunological and occasionally neurological effects which are harmful to the body, and other [[Gram-positive]] cocci, such as [[pneumococci]] and [[streptococci]], and certain fungi as well as Gram-positive bacterial toxins. Septic shock also includes some elements of cardiogenic shock. In 1992, the ACCP/SCCM Consensus Conference Committee defined septic shock: ". . .sepsis-induced hypotension (systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg or a reduction of 40 mmHg from baseline) despite adequate fluid resuscitation along with the presence of perfusion abnormalities that may include, but are not limited to, lactic acidosis, oliguria, or an acute alteration in mental status. Patients who are receiving inotropic or vasopressor agents may have a normalized blood pressure at the time that perfusion abnormalities are identified." *[[Anaphylactic shock]] is caused by a severe [[Anaphylaxis|anaphylactic reaction]] to an [[allergen]], [[antigen]], [[drug]] or foreign protein causing the release of [[histamine]] which causes widespread vasodilation, leading to hypotension and increased capillary permeability. *High spinal injuries may cause [[neurogenic shock]]. The classic symptoms include [[bradycardia|a slow heartrate]] due to loss of cardiac [[sympathetic nervous system|sympathetic tone]] and warm skin due to dilation of the peripheral blood vessels. (This term can be confused with [[spinal shock]] which is a recoverable loss of function of the [[spinal cord]] after injury and does not refer to the haemodynamic instability per se.) ===Endocrine=== Based on [[endocrine]] disturbances such as: *[[Hypothyroidism]] (can be considered a form of [[cardiogenic shock]]) in people who are critically ill patients, reduces [[cardiac output]] and can lead to [[hypotension]] and respiratory insufficiency. *[[Hyperthyroidism|Thyrotoxicosis]] ([[cardiogenic shock]]) may induce a reversible cardiomyopathy. *Acute [[adrenal insufficiency]] ([[distributive shock]]) is frequently the result of discontinuing [[corticosteroid]] treatment without tapering the dosage. However, surgery and intercurrent disease in patients on corticosteroid therapy without adjusting the dosage to accommodate for increased requirements may also result in this condition. *Relative adrenal insufficiency ([[distributive shock]]) in critically ill patients where present [[cortisol|hormone levels]] are insufficient to meet the higher demands ==Pathophysiology== [[Image:Shock-cell2.svg|500px|thumb|Effects of inadequate perfusion on cell function.]] There are four stages of shock. As it is a complex and continuous condition there is no sudden transition from one stage to the next.{{cite book|last=Armstrong|first=D.J.|year=2004|title=Shock|location=In: Alexander, M.F., Fawcett, J.N., Runciman, P.J. ''Nursing Practice. Hospital and Home. The Adult.''(2nd edition)|publisher=Edinburgh: Churchill Livingstone}} At a cellular level, shock is the process of oxygen demand becoming greater than oxygen supply. One of the key dangers of shock is that it progresses by a [[positive feedback]] mechanism. Poor blood supply leads to cellular damage, which results in an inflammatory response to increase blood flow to the affected area. This is normally very useful to match up blood supply level with tissue demand for nutrients. However, if enough tissue causes this, it will deprive vital nutrients from other parts of the body. Additionally, the ability of the circulatory system to meet this increase in demand causes saturation, and this is a major result, of which other parts of the body begin to respond in a similar way; thus, exacerbating the problem. Due to this chain of events, immediate treatment of shock is critical for survival. ===Initial=== During this stage, the state of hypoperfusion causes [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]]. Due to the lack of oxygen, the cells perform [[lactic acid fermentation]]. Since oxygen, the terminal electron acceptor in the electron transport chain, is not abundant, this slows down entry of [[pyruvate]] into the [[Citric acid cycle|Krebs cycle]], resulting in its accumulation. Accumulating pyruvate is converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase and hence lactate accumulates (causing [[lactic acidosis]]). ===Compensatory=== This stage is characterised by the body employing physiological mechanisms, including neural, hormonal and bio-chemical mechanisms in an attempt to reverse the condition. As a result of the [[acidosis]], the person will begin to [[hyperventilation|hyperventilate]] in order to rid the body of carbon dioxide (CO2). CO2 indirectly acts to acidify the blood and by removing it the body is attempting to raise the pH of the blood. The [[baroreceptors]] in the [[artery|arteries]] detect the resulting [[hypotension]], and cause the release of [[epinephrine]] and [[norepinephrine]]. Norepinephrine causes predominately [[vasoconstriction]] with a mild increase in [[heart rate]], whereas [[epinephrine]] predominately causes an increase in [[heart rate]] with a small effect on the [[Blood vessel|vascular]] tone; the combined effect results in an increase in [[blood pressure]]. The [[Renin–angiotensin system|renin–angiotensin axis]] is activated, and [[arginine vasopressin]] ([[Anti-diuretic hormone]]; ADH) is released to conserve fluid via the kidneys. These hormones cause the vasoconstriction of the [[kidneys]], [[gastrointestinal tract]], and other organs to divert blood to the heart, [[lungs]] and [[brain]]. The lack of blood to the [[renal]] system causes the characteristic low [[urine]] production. However the effects of the renin–angiotensin axis take time and are of little importance to the immediate [[homeostatic]] mediation of shock.{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} ===Progressive=== Should the cause of the crisis not be successfully treated, the shock will proceed to the progressive stage and the compensatory mechanisms begin to fail. Due to the decreased perfusion of the cells, [[sodium]] ions build up within while [[potassium]] ions leak out. As anaerobic metabolism continues, increasing the body's metabolic acidosis, the arteriolar smooth muscle and precapillary [[sphincters]] relax such that blood remains in the [[capillaries]].Kumar, Vinay; Abbas, Abul K.; Fausto, Nelson; & Mitchell, Richard N. (2007). ''Robbins Basic Pathology'' (8th ed.). Saunders Elsevier. pp. 102–103 {{ISBN|978-1-4160-2973-1}} Due to this, the hydrostatic pressure will increase and, combined with [[histamine]] release, this will lead to leakage of fluid and [[protein]] into the surrounding tissues. As this fluid is lost, the blood concentration and [[viscosity]] increase, causing sludging of the micro-circulation. The prolonged vasoconstriction will also cause the vital organs to be compromised due to reduced perfusion. If the bowel becomes sufficiently [[ischemic]], bacteria may enter the blood stream, resulting in the increased complication of [[septic shock|endotoxic shock]]. ===Refractory=== At this stage, the vital organs have failed and the shock can no longer be reversed. [[Brain damage]] and cell death are occurring, and death will occur imminently. One of the primary reasons that shock is irreversible at this point is that much cellular [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] has been degraded into [[adenosine]] in the absence of oxygen as an electron receptor in the mitochondrial matrix. Adenosine easily perfuses out of cellular membranes into extracellular fluid, furthering capillary [[vasodilation]], and then is transformed into [[uric acid]]. Because cells can only produce adenosine at a rate of about 2% of the cell's total need per hour, even restoring oxygen is futile at this point because there is no adenosine to [[phosphorylate]] into ATP. ==Diagnosis== The first change seen in shock is an increased [[cardiac output]] followed by a decrease in [[mixed venous oxygen saturation]] (SmvO2) as measured in the [[pulmonary artery]] via a [[pulmonary artery catheter]]. [[Central venous oxygen saturation]] (ScvO2) as measured via a central line correlates well with SmvO2 and are easier to acquire. If shock progresses [[anaerobic metabolism]] will begin to occur with an increased blood [[lactic acid]] as the result. While many laboratory tests are typically performed there is no test that either makes or excludes the diagnosis. A [[chest X-ray]] or emergency department ultrasound may be useful to determine volume state. ==Management== The best evidence exists for the treatment of [[septic shock]] in adults and as the pathophysiology appears similar in children and other types of shock treatment this has been extrapolated to these areas. Management may include securing the airway via [[intubation]] if necessary to decrease the work of breathing and for guarding against respiratory arrest. Oxygen supplementation, intravenous fluids, [[Passive leg raising test|passive leg raising]] (not [[Trendelenburg position]]) should be started and blood transfusions added if blood loss is severe. It is important to keep the person warm as well as adequately manage pain and anxiety as these can increase oxygen consumption. ===Fluids=== Aggressive intravenous fluids are recommended in most types of shock (e.g. 1–2 liter [[normal saline]] bolus over 10 minutes or 20 ml/kg in a child) which is usually instituted as the person is being further evaluated.{{cite book |author=American College of Surgeons |title=Atls, Advanced Trauma Life Support Program for Doctors |publisher=Amer College of Surgeons |location= |year=2008 |pages=58 |isbn=978-1-880696-31-6 |oclc= |doi= }} Which intravenous fluid is superior, [[colloids]] or [[Crystalloid fluid|crystalloids]], remains undetermined. Thus as crystalloids are less expensive they are recommended.{{Cite journal|last=Perel|first=Pablo|last2=Roberts|first2=Ian|last3=Ker|first3=Katharine|date=2013-02-28|title=Colloids versus crystalloids for fluid resuscitation in critically ill patients|url=|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|volume=|issue=2|pages=CD000567|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD000567.pub6|issn=1469-493X|pmid=23450531|via=}}{{Update inline|reason=Updated version https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30073665|date = November 2018}} If the person remains in shock after initial resuscitation [[packed red blood cells]] should be administered to keep the [[hemoglobin]] greater than 100 g/l. For those with haemorrhagic shock the current evidence supports limiting the use of fluids for penetrating thorax and abdominal injuries allowing mild [[hypotension]] to persist (known as [[permissive hypotension]]).{{cite book|title=Rosen's emergency medicine: concepts and clinical practice 7th edition|last=Marx|first=J|year=2010|publisher=Mosby/Elsevier|location=Philadelphia, PA|isbn=978-0-323-05472-0|page=2467}} Targets include a [[mean arterial pressure]] of 60 mmHg, a [[systolic blood pressure]] of 70–90 mmHg, or until their adequate mentation and peripheral pulses.{{cite journal|last=Cherkas|first=David|title=Traumatic Hemorrhagic Shock: Advances In Fluid Management|journal=Emergency Medicine Practice|date=Nov 2011|volume=13|issue=11|url=http://www.ebmedicine.net/store.php?paction=showProduct&catid=8&pid=244|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118152838/http://www.ebmedicine.net/store.php?paction=showProduct&catid=8&pid=244|archivedate=2012-01-18|df=}} [[Hypertonic fluid]] may also be an option in this group.{{cite journal|last1=Wu|first1=MC|last2=Liao|first2=TY|last3=Lee|first3=EM|last4=Chen|first4=YS|last5=Hsu|first5=WT|last6=Lee|first6=MG|last7=Tsou|first7=PY|last8=Chen|first8=SC|last9=Lee|first9=CC|title=Administration of Hypertonic Solutions for Hemorrhagic Shock: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Clinical Trials.|journal=Anesthesia & Analgesia|date=November 2017|volume=125|issue=5|pages=1549–1557|doi=10.1213/ANE.0000000000002451|pmid=28930937}} ===Medications=== [[Vasopressors]] may be used if blood pressure does not improve with fluids. There is no evidence of substantial superiority of one vasopressor over another; however, using dopamine leads to an increased risk of arrythmia when compared with norepinephrine.{{Cite journal|last=Gamper|first=Gunnar|last2=Havel|first2=Christof|last3=Arrich|first3=Jasmin|last4=Losert|first4=Heidrun|last5=Pace|first5=Nathan Leon|last6=Müllner|first6=Marcus|last7=Herkner|first7=Harald|date=2016-02-15|title=Vasopressors for hypotensive shock|url=|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|volume=2|pages=CD003709|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD003709.pub4|issn=1469-493X|pmid=26878401|via=}} Vasopressors have not been found to improve outcomes when used for [[hemorrhagic shock]] from [[Trauma (medical)|trauma]]{{cite journal|last=Diez|first=C|author2=Varon, AJ |title=Airway management and initial resuscitation of the trauma patient|journal=Current Opinion in Critical Care|date=December 2009|volume=15|issue=6|pages=542–7|pmid=19713836|doi=10.1097/MCC.0b013e328331a8a7}} but may be of use in [[neurogenic shock]].{{cite journal|last=Cocchi|first=MN|author2=Kimlin, E |author3=Walsh, M |author4=Donnino, MW |title=Identification and resuscitation of the trauma patient in shock|journal=Emergency Medicine Clinics of North America|date=August 2007|volume=25|issue=3|pages=623–42, vii|pmid=17826209|doi=10.1016/j.emc.2007.06.001|citeseerx=10.1.1.688.9838}} [[Activated protein C]] (Xigris) while once aggressively promoted for the management of [[septic shock]] has been found not to improve survival and is associated with a number of complications.{{Cite journal|last=Martí-Carvajal|first=Arturo J.|last2=Solà|first2=Ivan|last3=Gluud|first3=Christian|last4=Lathyris|first4=Dimitrios|last5=Cardona|first5=Andrés Felipe|date=2012-12-12|title=Human recombinant protein C for severe sepsis and septic shock in adult and paediatric patients|url=|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|volume=12|pages=CD004388|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004388.pub6|issn=1469-493X|pmid=23235609|via=}} Xigris was withdrawn from the market in 2011, and clinical trials were discontinued. The use of [[sodium bicarbonate]] is controversial as it has not been shown to improve outcomes.{{cite journal|last=Boyd|first=JH|author2=Walley, KR |title=Is there a role for sodium bicarbonate in treating lactic acidosis from shock?|journal=Current Opinion in Critical Care|date=August 2008|volume=14|issue=4|pages=379–83|pmid=18614899|doi=10.1097/MCC.0b013e3283069d5c}} If used at all it should only be considered if the pH is less than 7.0. ===Mechanical support=== *[[Intra-aortic balloon pump]] (IABP) *[[Ventricular assist device]] (VAD) *[[Artificial heart]] (TAH) *[[Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation]] (ECMO) ===Treatment goals=== The goal of treatment is to achieve a urine output of greater than 0.5 ml/kg/h, a [[central venous pressure]] of 8–12 mmHg and a [[mean arterial pressure]] of 65–95 mmHg. In trauma the goal is to stop the bleeding which in many cases requires surgical interventions. ==Epidemiology== Haemorrhagic shock occurs in about 1–2% of trauma cases. Up to one-third of people admitted to the [[intensive care unit]] (ICU) are in circulatory shock.{{cite journal|last1=Finfer|first1=Simon R.|last2=Vincent|first2=Jean-Louis|last3=Vincent|first3=Jean-Louis|last4=De Backer|first4=Daniel|title=Circulatory Shock|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|date=31 October 2013|volume=369|issue=18|pages=1726–1734|doi=10.1056/NEJMra1208943|pmid=24171518}} Of these, cardiogenic shock accounts for approximately 20%, hypovolemic about 20%, and septic shock about 60% of cases.{{Cite journal|last=Cecconi|first=Maurizio|last2=Backer|first2=Daniel De|last3=Antonelli|first3=Massimo|last4=Beale|first4=Richard|last5=Bakker|first5=Jan|last6=Hofer|first6=Christoph|last7=Jaeschke|first7=Roman|last8=Mebazaa|first8=Alexandre|last9=Pinsky|first9=Michael R.|date=2014-12-01|title=Consensus on circulatory shock and hemodynamic monitoring. Task force of the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine|journal=Intensive Care Medicine|language=en|volume=40|issue=12|pages=1795–1815|doi=10.1007/s00134-014-3525-z|issn=0342-4642|pmc=4239778|pmid=25392034}} ==Prognosis== The prognosis of shock depends on the underlying cause and the nature and extent of concurrent problems. Hypovolemic, anaphylactic and neurogenic shock are readily treatable and respond well to medical therapy. [[Septic shock]] however, is a grave condition with a mortality rate between 30% and 50%. The prognosis of [[cardiogenic shock]] is even worse with a mortality rate between 70% and 90%.{{cite book |last= Irwin |first= Richard S. |author2= Rippe, James M. |title= Intensive Care Medicine |url= http://www.lww.com/product/?0-7817-3548-3 |publisher= Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, Philadelphia & London |date= January 2003 |isbn= 978-0-7817-3548-3 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20051107202505/http://www.lww.com/product/?0-7817-3548-3 |archivedate= 2005-11-07 |df= }} ==History== In 1972 Hinshaw and Cox suggested the classification system for shock which is still used today. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | meshName = Shock | meshNumber = D012769 | ICD10 = {{ICD10|R|57| |r|50}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|785.50}} | DiseasesDB = 12013 | eMedicineSubj = emerg | eMedicineTopic = 531 | eMedicine_mult = {{eMedicine2|med|285}} {{eMedicine2|emerg|533}} | MedlinePlus = 000039 }} {{Intensive care medicine}} {{Cardiovascular system symptoms and signs}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shock (Circulatory)}} [[Category:Intensive care medicine]] [[Category:Medical emergencies]] [[Category:Causes of death]] [[Category:RTT]]

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{refimprove|date=April 2012}} {{Spiritualism_small}}
A '''spirit guide''', in western [[spiritualism]], is an entity that remains as a disincarnate [[spirit]] to act as a guide or protector to a living [[incarnation|incarnated]] human being.
== Description ==
According to [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophical]] doctrine, spirit guides are not always of human descent. Some spirit guides live as energy, in the cosmic realm, or as light beings, which are very high level spirit guides. Some spirit guides are persons who have lived many former lifetimes, paid their [[karma|karmic]] debts, and advanced beyond a need to reincarnate. Many devotees believe that spirit guides are chosen on "the other side" by human beings who are about to incarnate and wish assistance.
Some early modern Spiritualists did not favor the idea of spirit guides. Spiritualist author and medium E.W. Wallis, writing in ''A Guide to Mediumship and Psychic Unfoldment'', expressed an opinion that the notion of spirit guides is disempowering and disrespectful to both spirits and living people. He does not deny that seeking people may be helped by spirits here and there, but decries the idea that said spirits are appointed or assigned to do nothing but help the living. He advises would-be mediums to steer clear of the notion that they are being "guided" unless they have demonstrable proof that such is the case.<ref>Wallis, E.W. and M.H., ''A Guide to Mediumship and Psychic Unfoldment.'' Originally published 1901. Reprint edition by Health Research 1996, p. 162-3, 193.</ref>
== Firsthand accounts == [[Theresa Caputo]], The Long Island Medium, simply calls her guide "Spirit", describing it as an entity that she has been able to sense since she was four years old.<ref>Gilbert, Ryan (June 26, 2012). [http://articles.courant.com/2012-06-26/entertainment/hc-theresa-caputo-0627-20120626_1_spiritual-medium-cameras-gift "Theresa Caputo Says Life As 'Long Island Medium' Is 'Bananas'"]. ''[[Hartford Courant]]''.</ref>
[[Spiritualism (religious movement)|American Spiritualists]] of the 19th and 20th centuries often described their guides as resembling [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]]s. One popular spirit guide of this type, encountered by many Anglo-American Spiritualists, was named White Hawk. Among African-American Spiritualists, especially those in churches that were founded by or influenced by Mother [[Leafy Anderson]], the Native American guide was named [[Black Hawk (chief)|Black Hawk]], and was presumed to be the spirit of the [[Sauk people|Sac]] tribe warrior of the same name.<ref>Berry, Jason (November 1, 1995). ''The Spirit of Blackhawk: A Mystery of Africans and Indians''. [[University Press of Mississippi]].</ref>
== See also == * [[Channeler]] * [[Dream guide]] * [[Spiritualism]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Deities and spirits]] [[Category:Spirituality]] [[Category:Spiritualism]]

{{Infobox civilian attack |title=SuccessTech Academy shooting |image= |image_size= |caption= |location=[[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], U.S. |target= |date=Wednesday, October 10, 2007 |time=c. 1:06 p.m.<ref name='CNN1'>{{cite news |agency= [[Associated Press]] | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Report: Teen shoots four; kills self at Cleveland high school | date=2007-10-10 | publisher=[[CNN]] | url =http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/10/10/cleveland.shooting/index.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-06 | language = }}</ref> |timezone=[[UTC-5|EST]] |type=[[School shooting]] |fatalities=1 (the perpetrator) |injuries=5 (4 from gunfire) |perp=Asa H. Coon |weapons = * [[.22 Long Rifle|.22]]-[[caliber]] [[revolver]] * [[.38 Special|.38-caliber]] [[revolver]] * Three [[Knife|folding knives]] }}
The '''SuccessTech Academy shooting''' was a [[school shooting]] that occurred on October 10, 2007, at the [[SuccessTech Academy|SuccessTech]] alternative high school in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], [[United States]]. Fourteen-year-old freshman Asa H. Coon shot two students and two teachers before committing [[suicide]] on the fourth floor of the building.
==Shooting== On Wednesday, October 10, 2007, Asa H. Coon entered the five-story school building shortly before 1:00 p.m. EST, armed with two handguns (a [[.22 long rifle|.22-caliber]] [[revolver]] and a [[.38 Special|.38-caliber]] [[revolver]]),<ref name="clevelandfourshot" /><ref name='NYTimes 2007-10-11'>{{cite news | first=Chris | last=Maag |author2=[[Ian Urbina]] |authorlink= | title=Student, 14, Shoots 4 and Kills Himself in Cleveland School | date=2007-10-10 | publisher= | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/11/us/11cleveland.html?_r=1&hp&oref=slogin | work =[[The New York Times]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-02-25 | language = }}</ref><!-- Some sources may state that both the guns were only .22-calibers although more recent sources state that they are both .22 and .38-calibers --> and a box of additional rounds of ammunition for each pistol; three [[Knife#Folding blade features|folding knive]]s were also in Coon's possession, which were all stocked together in a [[duffel bag]].<ref name='MSNBC 2007-10-10'>{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Police: Suspended boy shoots 4 at Ohio school | date=2007-10-10 | publisher=[[MSNBC]] | url =http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21224357/ | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-02-25 | language = }}</ref> Wearing a [[Marilyn Manson]] concert shirt, black jeans, and black-painted fingernails,<ref name="5 Hospitalized After 14-Year-Old Goes on Shooting Rampage at Cleveland High School">[http://www.foxnews.com/story/2007/10/11/5-hospitalized-after-14-year-old-goes-on-shooting-rampage-at-cleveland-high/ "5 Hospitalized After 14-Year-Old Goes on Shooting Rampage at Cleveland High School"]</ref> Coon walked to the fourth floor of the building and entered the men's washroom where he loaded two revolvers.<ref name="plaindealershothimself" /> {| style="float:left; margin:1em 1em 1em 1em; width:18em; border: 1px solid #a0a0a0; padding: 10px; background-color: #F5F5F5; text-align:left;" |- style="text-align:center;" |'''Victims'''<ref name="WKYC-TV"> {{cite web | first=Caitlin | last=Kollar | title = School shooting victims on the mend | publisher = [[WKYC-TV|WKYC]] | date = 2007-10-11| url = http://www.wkyc.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=75946 | accessdate = 2007-10-12 }} </ref> |- style="text-align:left; font-size:x-small;" |1. '''Michael Peek''', age 14, student. |- style="text-align:left; font-size:x-small;" |2. '''Darnell Rodgers''', age 17, student. |- style="text-align:left; font-size:x-small;" |3. '''Michael Grassie''', age 42, social studies teacher. |- style="text-align:left; font-size:x-small;" |4. '''David Kachadourian''', age 57, math teacher. |- style="text-align:left; font-size:x-small;" |} The shooting began at approximately 1:06 p.m. on the fourth floor of the building, after 14-year-old Michael Peek punched Coon in the face for bumping into him. When Peek walked away, Coon shot him in the [[abdomen]].<ref name="clevelandfourshot">{{cite web | title = Four shot at school, gunman kills himself | publisher = ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' | date = October 11, 2007 | url = http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?/schoolshooting/more/four_shot.html | first = Michael | last = O' Malley | author2 = Gabriel Baird | authorlink = | accessdate = 2009-03-01 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090413185847/http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?%2Fschoolshooting%2Fmore%2Ffour_shot.html | archivedate = April 13, 2009 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = New Video Shows Student Terror in Ohio | publisher = ''[[Fox News]]''| date = October 11, 2007 | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,301065,00.html | first= | last= |authorlink= | accessdate = 2009-08-17 }}</ref><ref name="eschoolnews">{{cite web | title = Shooting rips Cleveland tech school | publisher = ''eSchool'' News | date = October 11, 2007 | url = http://www.eschoolnews.com/news/top-news/index.cfm?i=49098&CFID=5791735&CFTOKEN=29355084 | accessdate = 2009-02-07 }}</ref> Another student, 17-year-old Darnell Rodgers, suffered a graze gunshot wound to the elbow in the same hallway. Michael Grassie, a [[social studies]] teacher, was shot in the chest when Coon entered his classroom. A second teacher, David Kachadourian, was shot in the back of his shoulder while in the hallway evacuating his students.<ref name="clevelandfourshot" /><ref name='shepheredcleveland'>{{cite news | first=Scott | last=Stephens |authorlink= | title=Wounded SuccessTech teacher shepherded students to safety | date=2007-10-12 | publisher= | url =http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?/schoolshooting/more/teacher_shepherded.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-16 | language = }}</ref> During the entire shooting, Coon was said to be cursing.<ref name="5 Hospitalized After 14-Year-Old Goes on Shooting Rampage at Cleveland High School"/> The shooting ended when Coon entered another room and fatally shot himself in the right side of his head.<ref name="plaindealershothimself">{{cite web | title = SuccessTech shooter shot himself in the head | publisher = ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' | date = October 11, 2007 | url = http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2007/10/success_tech_shooter_shot_hims.html | accessdate = 2009-01-24| first= Donna | last= Miller}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Ohio school shooter had history of problems | publisher = [[CNN]] | date = October 11, 2007 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/10/11/cleveland.shooting/index.html | accessdate = 2007-10-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011135551/http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/10/11/cleveland.shooting/index.html |archivedate = 2007-10-11}}</ref><ref name='washington1011'>{{cite news | first=Joe | last=Milicia |authorlink= | title=4 Hurt, Gunman Killed in Ohio School | date=2007-10-11 | publisher= | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/10/AR2007101001486.html | work =[[The Washington Post]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref>
The school was placed on [[Code Blue (emergency code)|Code Blue]] lockdown shortly after the shooting. The two injured teachers were treated at [[MetroHealth Medical Center]], and the two students injured were treated at the [[Rainbow Babies & Children's Hospital]].<ref name='CNN1' /><ref name='insideacctplain'>{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=An inside account of school shooting | date=2007-10-10 | publisher=[[The Plain Dealer]] | url =http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?/schoolshooting/more/insideaccount.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-16 | language = }}</ref> A 14-year-old student, Trinnetta McGrady, was also hospitalized for knee and back injuries received from being trampled in a hallway by fleeing students.<ref name='nytiems10112'>{{cite news | first=Chris | last=Maag |author2=[[Ian Urbina]] |authorlink= | title=Student, 14, Shoots 4 and Kills Himself in Cleveland School | date=2007-10-11 | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/11/us/11cleveland.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-11 | language = }}</ref> Kachadourian and Rodgers were discharged later that day, while Peek and McGrady were released the following day.<ref name='newsnet5'>{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Video From Cameras Inside School To Be Reviewed | date=2007-10-11 | publisher=[[WEWS-TV]] | url =http://www.newsnet5.com/news/14318677/detail.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-16 | language = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071029134639/http://www.newsnet5.com/news/14318677/detail.html |archivedate = 2007-10-29}}</ref> Grassie was discharged from MetroHealth Medical Center on October 15.<ref name='mtvnews1016'>{{cite news | first=Gil | last=Kaufman |authorlink= | title=Cleveland School Reopens After Shooting; Teacher Recalls Look Of 'Total Anger' On Gunman's Face | date=2007-10-16 | publisher=[[MTV News]] | url =http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1572036/20071016/index.jhtml | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-16 | language = }}</ref><ref name='foxfailhistory' />
===Motives=== Asa Coon had been placed on a three-day suspension two days prior to the shooting for an altercation with another student regarding the existence of [[God]].<ref name='whowasasa'>{{cite news | first=Scott | last=Stephens |author2=Rachel Dissell |authorlink= | title=School shooter has record of violence, suicidal talk but was called genius by some | date=2007-10-11 | publisher= | url =http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?/schoolshooting/more/who_was.html | work =[[The Plain Dealer]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref><ref name='foxnewsgunmansbroarrested'>{{cite news |agency= [[Associated Press]]| first= | last= |authorlink= | title=New Video Shows Student Terror in Ohio; Gunman's Brother Arrested | date=2007-10-11 | url =http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,301065,00.html | publisher =[[Fox News]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-02-28 | language = }}</ref> According to Coon's uncle, Larry Looney, Coon said he was upset because the teachers would not listen to what he had to say regarding the fight.<ref name='ustoday1012upset'>{{cite news | first=Joe | last=Milicia|authorlink= | title=Gunman's uncle: Teen upset with teachers | date=2007-10-12 | publisher= | url =https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-10-12-cleveland-uncle_N.htm | work =[[USA Today]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-03 | language = }}</ref> According to fellow students and teachers, Coon had apparently been the target of [[bullying]] by students at the school for his [[Gothic fashion|Gothic]]-appearance and eccentric behavior, and had made threats of violence in front of students and teachers the week before the shooting.<ref name='NYTimes 2007-10-11' /><ref name='washington1011' /><ref name='ctvca'>{{cite news |agency= [[Associated Press]] |first= | last= |authorlink= | title=School gunman had access despite threats | date=2007-10-11 | publisher=[[CTV News]] | url =http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20071010/school_shoot_071011?s_name=&no_ads= | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref> Joseph Fletcher, a friend of Coon, said he had been "pushed too far" and that teachers were unable to help with his problems.<ref name='pushedtoofar'>{{cite news | first=Patrick | last=O'Donnell |authorlink= | title=Shooter "pushed too far" | date=2007-10-10 | publisher= | url =http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2007/10/shooter_pushed_too_far.html | work =[[The Plain Dealer]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref> Michael Grassie, who was one of Coon's teachers, said that Coon was frustrated because he was given a failing grade in his World History class,<ref name='failinggrassieclass'>{{cite news | first=Joseph L. | last=Wagner |authorlink= | title=Shooter Asa Coon was failing, says wounded SuccessTech teacher Michael Grassie | date=2007-10-16 | publisher= | url =http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?/schoolshooting/more/failing.html | work =[[The Plain Dealer]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref> and had made attempts to urge him into a fight.<ref name='foxfailhistory'>{{cite news |agency= [[Associated Press]]| first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Teacher: Cleveland School Shooter Upset About Failing History | date=2007-10-15 | publisher=[[Fox News]] | url =http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,302025,00.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref> [[Juvenile Court]] records show that Coon had a criminal history and mental health problems since 2005, and threatened to commit suicide while in a [[mental health facility]] in summer 2006.<ref name='washington1011' /><ref name='pressdemo'>{{cite news | first=Joe | last=Milicia |authorlink= | title=Cleveland boy shoots 4, himself at school | date=2007-10-11 | publisher= | url =http://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/20071011/NEWS/710110398 | work =[[The Press Democrat]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref>
==Aftermath== At 2:50 p.m., an hour-and-a-half after the shooting, [[List of mayors of Cleveland|Cleveland Mayor]] [[Frank G. Jackson]] announced in a news conference that five people, including three students, were hurt in a shooting at the SuccessTech Academy. Four of them having been shot; the students being in "stable" condition and the adults being in a more "elevated" state.<ref name='wkycannouncement'>{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=School shooting: 4 shot; gunman takes own life; police say teen led troubled life | date=2007-10-10 | publisher=[[WKYC]] | url =http://www.wkyc.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=75854 | work =| pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-15 | language = }}</ref>
Classes throughout the Cleveland Metropolitan School District were canceled the following two days (resumed on Monday, October 15), and classes at SuccessTech Academy did not resume until Tuesday, October 16.<ref name='reopeningplain'>{{cite news | first=Jesse | last=Tinsley |authorlink= | title=Cleveland schools reopen today, with new security plan | date=2007-10-15 | publisher= | url =http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?/schoolshooting/more/reopen.html | work =[[The Plain Dealer]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref> Cleveland's public school system established an anonymous [[hotline]] for students to report threats and dangerous behavior. The school system also announced plans to install [[metal detector]]s in all its schools and hire additional armed security guards to patrol the campuses, These changes are estimated to cost the district US$3.3 million.<ref name='reopeningplain ' /> Schools were instructed to implement additional security precautions, to be reviewed by a professional security firm.<ref name="WKYC2"> {{cite web | title = Crime scene photograph from school shooting makes way to Internet | publisher = [[WKYC]] | url = http://www.wkyc.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=76168 | accessdate = 2007-10-15 }} </ref>
A crime scene photo taken of Coon after his suicide was posted by Cleveland [[disc jockey]] Shane French (Rover) on a webpage promoting ''[[Rover's Morning Glory]]'' and soon taken down. Mayor Jackson called the photo, which he didn't see, "extremely inappropriate".<ref>[http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/index.ssf/2007/10/internet_posting_of_asa_coon_d.html "Internet posting of Asa Coon death photo tracked", by Amanda Garret, ''The Plain Dealer'']</ref> Cleveland police officer Walter Emerick, who took the picture using his cell phone camera, was suspended from duty for eight days for sending the photo to other people, who eventually [[Internet leak|leaked it to the Internet]].<ref name='officesuspensionplain'>{{cite news | first=Mark | last=Puente |author2=Patrick O'Donnell |authorlink= | title=Asa Coon's photo on Web results in officer's suspension | date=2007-12-18 | publisher= | url =http://www.cleveland.com/schoolshooting/plaindealer/index.ssf?/schoolshooting/more/photo_taken.html | work =[[The Plain Dealer]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | language = }}</ref>

{{About|influenza viruses in pigs|the 2009 outbreak|2009 flu pandemic|the 2009 human virus|Pandemic H1N1/09 virus}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Swine flu | synonyms = Pig influenza, swine flu, hog flu, pig flu | image = H1N1 influenza virus.jpg | alt = | caption = [[Electron microscope]] image of the [[reassortment|reassorted]] H1N1 influenza virus photographed at the CDC Influenza Laboratory. The viruses are 80–120 [[nanometre]]s in diameter.{{cite web|author=International Committee on onomy of Viruses |title=The Universal Virus Database, version 4: Influenza A |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ICTVdb/ICTVdB/00.046.0.01.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100113220345/http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ICTVdb/ICTVdB/00.046.0.01.htm |archivedate=January 13, 2010 }} | field = [[Infectious disease (medical specialty)|Infectious disease]] | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Swine influenza''' is an infection caused by any one of several types of swine [[influenza]] [[virus]]es. '''Swine influenza virus''' ('''SIV''') or '''swine-origin influenza virus''' ('''S-OIV''') is any strain of the [[Orthomyxoviridae|influenza family of viruses]] that is [[endemism|endemic]] in [[pig]]s.{{cite journal|url=http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/121407.htm|title=Swine influenza|journal=The Merck Veterinary Manual|year=2008|accessdate=April 30, 2009|isbn=1-4421-6742-4}} As of 2009, the known SIV strains include [[Influenzavirus C|influenza C]] and the subtypes of [[Influenza A Virus|influenza A]] known as [[H1N1]], [[H1N2]], H2N1, [[H3N1]], [[H3N2]], and [[H2N3]]. The Swine flu was initially seen in humans in Mexico in 2009, where the strain of the particular virus was a mixture from 3 types of strains.{{Cite journal|last=Gibbs|first=Adrian J.|last2=Armstrong|first2=John S.|last3=Downie|first3=Jean C.|date=2009-01-01|title=From where did the 2009 'swine-origin' influenza A virus (H1N1) emerge?|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/1743-422X-6-207|journal=Virology Journal|volume=6|pages=207|doi=10.1186/1743-422X-6-207|issn=1743-422X|pmc=2787513|pmid=19930669}} Six of the genes are very similar to the H1N2 influenza virus that was found in pigs around 2000. Swine influenza virus is common throughout pig populations worldwide. Transmission of the virus from pigs to humans is not common and does not always lead to [[human flu]], often resulting only in the production of [[antibody|antibodies]] in the blood. If transmission does cause human flu, it is called [[zoonosis|zoonotic]] swine flu. People with regular exposure to pigs are at increased risk of swine flu infection. Around the mid-20th century, identification of influenza subtypes became possible, allowing accurate diagnosis of transmission to humans. Since then, only 50 such transmissions have been confirmed. These strains of swine flu rarely pass from human to human. Symptoms of zoonotic swine flu in humans are similar to those of [[influenza]] and of [[influenza-like illness]] in general, namely [[chills]], [[fever]], [[pharyngitis|sore throat]], [[myalgia|muscle pains]], severe [[headache]], [[cough]]ing, [[fatigue (medical)|weakness]], shortness of breath, and [[malaise|general discomfort]]. In August 2010, the [[World Health Organization]] declared the swine flu [[pandemic]] officially over.{{cite web|title=Pandemic (H1N1) 2009|url=http://www.who.int/csr/disease/swineflu/en/}}{{cite web|title=Swine Flu - National Health Portal of India|url=https://www.nhp.gov.in/disease/respiratory/respiratory-tract/swine-flu}} Cases of swine flu have been reported in [[India]], with over [[2015 Indian swine flu outbreak|31,156 positive test cases and 1,841 deaths]] up to March 2015.{{cite web|url=http://m.thehindu.com/sci-tech/health/swine-flu-toll-inches-towards-1900-no-of-cases-crosses-31000/article7011912.ece/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150320080119/http://m.thehindu.com/sci-tech/health/swine-flu-toll-inches-towards-1900-no-of-cases-crosses-31000/article7011912.ece/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 20, 2015|title=Swine flu toll inches towards 1,900|author=PTI|publisher=''[[The Hindu]]''|date=March 19, 2015|accessdate=March 20, 2015}} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Signs and symptoms== In swine, an influenza infection produces [[fever]], [[lethargy]], [[sneezing]], [[coughing]], [[Dyspnea|difficulty breathing]] and decreased appetite. In some cases the infection can cause [[miscarriage]]. Although mortality is usually low (around 1–4%), the virus can produce [[weight loss]] and [[Growth failure|poor growth]], causing economic loss to farmers. Infected pigs can lose up to 12 pounds of body weight over a three- to four-week period. Swine have receptors to which both avian and mammalian influenza viruses are able to bind to, which leads to the virus being able to evolve and mutate into different forms.{{Cite journal|last=Thacker|first=Eileen|last2=Janke|first2=Bruce|date=2008-02-15|title=Swine Influenza Virus: Zoonotic Potential and Vaccination Strategies for the Control of Avian and Swine Influenzas|url=http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/197/Supplement_1/S19|journal=Journal of Infectious Diseases|language=en|volume=197|issue=Supplement 1|pages=S19–S24|doi=10.1086/524988|issn=0022-1899|pmid=18269323}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Influenza A is responsible for infecting swine, and was first identified in the summer of 1918. Pigs have often been seen as "mixing vessels", which help to change and evolve strains of disease that are then passed on to other mammals, such as humans. ===Humans=== [[File:PD Diagram of swine flu symptoms EN.svg|thumb|Main symptoms of swine flu in humans{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/swineflu/key_facts.htm|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |title=Key Facts about Swine Influenza (Swine Flu)|accessdate=April 27, 2009}}]] Direct transmission of a swine flu virus from pigs to humans is occasionally possible ([[zoonosis|zoonotic]] swine flu).{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} In all, 50 cases are known to have occurred since the first report in medical literature in 1958, which have resulted in a total of six deaths.{{Cite journal|vauthors=Myers KP, Olsen CW, Gray GC |title=Cases of Swine Influenza in Humans: A Review of the Literature|journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases|volume=44|issue=8|pages=1084–8|date=April 2007|pmid=17366454|pmc=1973337|doi=10.1086/512813}} Of these six people, one was pregnant, one had [[leukemia]], one had [[Hodgkin's lymphoma]] and two were known to be previously healthy. One of these had unknown whereabouts. Despite these apparently low numbers of infections, the true rate of infection may be higher, since most cases only cause a very mild disease, and will probably never be reported or diagnosed. [[File:Video xo.ogv|thumb|In this video, Dr. Joe Bresee, with CDC's Influenza Division, describes the symptoms of swine flu and warning signs to look for that indicate the need for urgent medical attention.
